content: The number of non-U.S. citizens enrolling in U.S. colleges and universities slowed after 9/11 due to visa policies and global competition. However, a 2009 report showed a significant 8.0% increase in foreign-born students for the 2008-2009 academic year, with a notable rise in students from China. New foreign student enrollment also increased by 16.0%, attributed to recruitment efforts and improved visa processing. The increase in international student enrollment for the 2008-2009 academic year is attributed to recruitment efforts and improved visa processing. The top countries of origin for foreign students were India, China, South Korea, Canada, Japan, Taiwan, Mexico, Turkey, Vietnam, and Saudi Arabia. The top fields of study for foreign students were business and management, engineering, physical and life sciences, social sciences, mathematics and computer sciences, health professions, and fine and applied arts. Tracking foreign students attending U.S. institutions has generated particular debate following the September 11th terrorist attacks. Prior to September 11th, the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act authorized the SEVP/CIPRIS program to track foreign students and researchers. However, the system was never fully implemented due to cost concerns and described as an unnecessary burden on colleges and universities. The USA Patriot Act and the Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act enhanced the process for monitoring foreign students and researchers in U.S. institutions. The INS developed SEVIS, a web-based system, to maintain current information on foreign students and exchange visitors to ensure they comply with visa requirements. Congress mandated the tracking system to be operational by February 15, 2003. The deadline for implementing SEVIS was extended to February 15, 2003, but it faced delays due to technical issues and increased visa applicant screening. A proposal for SEVIS II aims to address these problems and enhance the tracking system. A hearing in 2005 focused on correcting visa process vulnerabilities. The International Relations hearing addressed gaps in the visa process, focusing on strengthening security measures while facilitating legitimate travel. Witnesses highlighted increased consular workloads, lack of resources and training, and the need for clear procedures to ensure consistent visa adjudication worldwide. The Government Accountability Office (GAO) has released reports on visa processing improvements and recommended changes in visa operations to address delays and enhance national security. Recommendations include clarifying visa policies, providing necessary tools for consular officers, and ensuring consistent visa adjudication worldwide. Comprehensive immigration reform legislation, including H.R. 4321, has been introduced in the 111th Congress. The bill aims to exempt certain U.S.-educated immigrants from employment-based immigration limits and make changes to H-1B visa employer application requirements. Additionally, other bills related to immigration have also been introduced in the same Congress. Several bills introduced in the 111th Congress aim to address issues related to H-1B visas and foreign students in scientific and technical disciplines. H.R. 1736 focuses on international science and technology cooperation, while S. 887 seeks to reform H-1B employer requirements. H.R. 1791 aims to limit the departure of trained Ph.D.s from the American economy. H.R. 1791, the STAPLE Act, aims to limit the departure of trained Ph.D.s from the American economy by imposing numerical limitations on immigrants with doctorate degrees in scientific disciplines from U.S. institutions. It also sets restrictions on H-1B visas for immigrants with doctorates in scientific disciplines.
